title: How to watch the Olympic track cycling events: schedule, TV guide, streaming and more
content:
Track cycling comes to the fore at Tokyo’s Izu Velodrome this week, with 12 gold medals up for grabs over seven days of racing.

With the Tokyo 2020 road, mountain biking and BMX events done and dusted, eyes will turn to the boards between Monday 2 August and Sunday 8 August.

So far in Japan, we’ve seen Richard Carapaz (Ecuador) and Anna Kiesenhofer (Austria) win the men’s and women’s road races, before Primož Roglič (Slovenia) and Annemiek van Vleuten (Netherlands) stood on the top step of the podium in the time trial events.

Tom Pidcock won Great Britain’s first cycling medal of Tokyo 2020 in the men’s cross-country MTB race, dominating on this unbranded BMC Fourstroke, while Jolanda Neff (Switzerland) added to her world titles with gold in the women’s race. We’ve looked back on some of the XC tech talking points from Tokyo 2020.

In the BMX events, Beth Shriever and Charlotte Worthington doubled up for Team GB in the women’s race and freestyle respectively, while Niek Kimmann (Netherlands) took men’s BMX race gold and Logan Martin (Australia) won the men’s freestyle event.

Olympic track cycling TV coverage and streaming in the UK, USA and Australia

How can I watch track cycling at the Olympic Games in the UK?

The BBC will be providing blanket coverage of the Olympic Games, so viewers in the UK can tune in whenever they wish to watch the best of the cycling action.

As the main rights holder to the Olympic Games, Eurosport (and GCN+) will also be broadcasting all cycling events.

How can I watch track cycling at the Olympic Games in the USA?

NBC will be the place to go for US viewers, with all coverage in the United States broadcast by NBC and its affiliates – this includes both live and delayed coverage.

How can I watch track cycling at the Olympic Games in Australia?

Channel 7 is the team behind blanket Olympic coverage in Australia, with 7Plus boasting more than 40 channels to ensure you don’t miss any of the events you are interested in.

Time differences from Japan for Olympic coverage

  • British Summer Time (BST): –8 hours
  • Eastern Standard Time (EST): –13 hours
  • Pacific Time (PT): –16 hours
  • Australian Eastern Standard Time: ＋1 hour

Schedule of track cycling events at the Tokyo Olympic Games

Alex Whitehead / SWPix.com

With the road, MTB and BMX medals settled, track cycling takes over on Monday 2 August, with medals up for grabs every day from then on until the final day of the Games on Sunday 8 August.

There are six disciplines in total – the team pursuit, sprint, madison, omnium, keirin and team sprint – with men’s and women’s events for each.

Want to know more? We’ve got a separate guide to Olympic track cycling events, as well as a guide to all the key Olympic track bikes.

Otherwise, here’s when you can tune in to the action. All times are BST (British Summer Time). We’ve highlighted each of the finals in bold.

Monday 2 August – 7:30am-10:30am

  • Men’s team pursuit – qualifying
  • Women’s team pursuit – qualifying
  • Women’s team sprint – heats, semi-finals, final (10:09am)

Tuesday 3 August – 7:30am-10:10am

  • Men’s team pursuit – heats
  • Women’s team pursuit – heats, semi-finals, final (09:26am)
  • Men’s team sprint – qualifying, heats, semi-finals, final (09:44am)

Wednesday 4 August – 7:50am-11am

  • Men’s team pursuit – semi-finals, final (10:06am)
  • Men’s sprint – qualifying, heats
  • Women’s keirin – heats

Thursday 5 August – 7:30am-10:50am

  • Women’s keirin – quarter-finals, semi-finals, final (09:45am)
  • Men’s omnium – scratch race, tempo race, elimination race, points race (final event – 09:55pm)
  • Men’s sprint – heats, quarter-finals

Friday 6 August – 7:30am-11:15am

  • Men’s sprint – semi-finals, final (10:35am)
  • Women’s madison– final (09:15am)
  • Women’s sprint – qualifying, heats

Saturday 7 August – 7:30am-10:25am

  • Men’s madison – final (08:55am)
  • Men’s keirin – heats
  • Women’s sprint – heats, quarter-finals

Sunday 8 August – 2am-5:15am

  • Men’s keirin – quarter-finals, semi-finals, final (4am)
  • Women’s omnium – scratch race, tempo race, elimination race, points race (final event – 4:25am)
  • Women’s sprint – semi-finals, final (4:05am)
